questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, and an eFAST was performed. What is the additional view that is not possible with FAST but is possible with eFAST?
questions.solution:
Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is extended into the thoracic cavities and peri­cardium (eFAST), where anterior pleural views are incorporated. It is a technique in which ultrasonography is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity. 

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography, used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

The patient is placed in a supine position. The following regions are scanned:

  • Subxiphoid transverse view (also called subcostal view or pericardial view)
  • Right upper quadrant view (also called right flank view or perihepatic view)
  • Left upper quadrant view (also called perisplenic or left flank view) 
  • Suprapubic view or pelvic view

An extended FAST or eFAST scan incorporates the anterior pleural views to assess the anterior thorax.

Drawbacks of FAST:

  • Does not reliably detect less than 100 mL of free blood
  • Does not directly identify hollow viscus injury or penetrating trauma
  • Often requires supplementing with other investigations
  • Does not assess the retroperitoneum

questions.text: Three weeks following a parotidectomy,  there is an aberrant regeneration of postganglionic parasympathetic fibers of the nerve marked in the image below.  All the following methods are suitable in order to prevent such occurrence except

choices.text: Artificial membrane between skin and parotid bed

questions.solution:
After parotidectomy, the aberrent regeneration of the postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve (marked in the image) leads to Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating). All the above-mentioned methods are suitable to prevent its occurrence except tympanic neurectomy because it is not a preventive method but is a method of treatment.

Patients with Frey's syndrome present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

The diagnosis can be confirmed with a starch-iodine test. This test involves painting the patient’s surgical site with iodine and dry starch, and a stimulus that can cause salivation is given to the patient. In the presence of iodine and sweat, the starch over the affected area will turn blue or brown.

It is an inevitable consequence of parotidectomy unless preventive measures are taken. These measures replace the barrier between the skin and the parotid bed and minimize the abnormal regeneration of autonomic nerve fibers. The preventive measures are:

  • Sternomastoid muscle flap
  • Temporalis fascial flap
  • Insertion of artificial membranes between the skin and the parotid bed.
Treatment of Frey's syndrome is with antiperspirants, tympanic neurectomy, or botulinum toxin injection into the affected area (most effective).

questions.text: A patient with degenerative high axial myopia was found to have an outward curvature of a part of the globe when indirect ophthalmoscopy was performed.  Which among the following is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The most common staphyloma to be associated with a degenerative high axial myopia is Posterior staphyloma.

Staphyloma refers to ectasia of the outer coats of the eye- cornea or sclera or both, as a result of the weakening of the eyewall due to inflammation or degenerative diseases. The staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

Types of Staphyloma:

  • Posterior staphyloma: Ectasia of the posterior pole of the eye and is lined by the choroid. The ectatic portion is detected by fundoscopy and B-scan ultrasonography. Indirect ophthalmoscopy shows a posterior outward curvature of the globe seen as a crescentic shadow in the macular region. The retinal vessels dip down into the region. The staphylomatous area appears pale due to degeneration of the retina, pigment epithelium, and occasionally the choroid. The most common cause is degenerative high axial myopia.
  • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium. The most common cause is a perforated sloughing corneal ulcer.
  • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body. Common causes include:
    • perforating injuries and ulcers of the peripheral cornea
    • anterior scleritis
    • scleromalacia perforans
    • poor wound apposition after complicated cataract surgery
    • secondary glaucoma
  • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. Causes include:
    • Developmental glaucoma, end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma
    • Scleritis
    • Ciliary trauma
  • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye. Causes include:
    • Scleritis
    • Degenerative myopia
    • Chronic uncontrolled glaucoma
 

Treatment: Local excision and repair with a corneal and scleral patch graft. Enucleation and replacement with an implant can be done for disfigured and blind eyes. Degenerative diseases responsible should be treated early to prevent secondary glaucoma and staphyloma formation.

questions.text: Following general anaesthesia for a procedure, a 45-year-old lady experienced prolonged somnolescence. On administration of physostigmine, she showed rapid improvement of her mental status. Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of the central anticholinergic syndrome, which is not caused by glycopyrrolate. 

Glycopyrrolate usually does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome because is a quaternary amine compound, lipid insoluble, and does not cross the blood-brain barrier. Glycopyrrolate blocks the peripheral muscarinic side effects (caused by increased acetylcholine levels by neostigmine) without causing unwanted central anticholinergic effects.

Drugs that can cause anticholinergic syndrome include:

  • Atropine
  • Scopolamine
  • First-generation antihistamines 
  • Tricyclic antidepressants 
  • Phenothiazines

The anticholinergic syndrome can present with central manifestations ranging from delirium and agitation to CNS depression, stupor and coma. It is a rare reaction due to either overdose or any unusual reaction to the usage of the drugs mentioned above. Physostigmine is useful in reversing the central anticholinergic syndrome produced by overdosage or an unusual reaction to these drugs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman presented with mild dyspareunia. Examination revealed a non-tender, mobile, fluctuant swelling on the vaginal wall. Ultrasound examination revealed a single cyst of size approximately 2 cm, independent from the bowel and bladder. The cyst arises from the part in the image labeled as A. Structure A is a remnant of what?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of a Gartner's duct cyst, which develops from the Gartner's duct (marked as A), a remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct). 

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient is unable to initiate speech or any voluntary movements but seems to be alert and aware of his surroundings with respect to his eye movements. Which among the following conditions is this clinical feature not associated with?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is describing akinetic mutism, which is not likely to be seen in Pick's disease, which is cortical dementia.

In akinetic mutism, there is an absence of voluntary movements and speech in a patient who appears alert and aware of their surroundings (as evidenced by eye movements). It is sometimes also referred to as coma vigil, a coma in which a patient appears to be asleep but can be aroused.

It can be seen in:

  • Psychotic depression
  • Schizophrenia with affective psychosis 
  • Catatonic states
  • Subcortical dementias
    • Huntington's disease
    • Parkinson's disease
    • Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
    • Vascular dementia
    • Wilson's disease
  • Brainstem tumors
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Pick's disease is cortical dementia, which presents with aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia. Other examples of cortical dementia include dementia in Alzheimer's disease and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the information obtained from the vaccine vial monitor 14 (VVM14) shown in the image below.

choices.text: It takes 14 days for the inner square to become darker than outer circle
It takes 14 days for the inner square and outer circle to reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the inner square and outer circle reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the outer circle color  becomes darker

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option 2.

The given scenario mentions VVM 14 (vaccine vial monitor 14), where 14 indicates the VVM number. It is the time in days for the inner square to reach the color of the outer circle when the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C. This color change signifies the discard point of the vial.

Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators that are routinely used to monitor vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain. It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

There are currently 4 types of VVMs, they are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccines based on the VVM number. 

  • VVM 30: High Stability
  • VVM 14: Medium Stability
  • VVM 7: Moderate Stability
  • VVM 2: Least Stable

If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Ensures that vaccines damaged by heat are not administered
  • Decision on which vaccines to be kept after a cold chain break occurs, minimizing unnecessary vaccine wastage
  • Decision on which vaccine is to be used first. Vaccines showing significant heat exposure should be used before those that show lower heat exposure, even if their expiry date is longer

There are two different locations for VVMs :

  • On the label of the vaccine: The vaccine vial, once opened, can be kept for subsequent immunization sessions for up to 28 days, regardless of the formulation of the product
  • In a location other than on the label (e.g., cap or neck of ampoule): The vaccine vial, once opened should be discarded at the end of the immunization session or within six hours of opening, whichever comes first, regardless of the formulation of the product

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Which among the following sinuses are visible in Caldwell's view?
questions.solution:
The sinuses visible in Caldwell's view are the frontal, ethmoid and maxillary sinuses, marked as 1, 2 and 4 in the image.

Structures seen in Caldwell's view are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

In Caldwell's view, the nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees caudally.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: A 40-year-old man working in the smelting industry presents with numbness and tingling in his toes and fingertips, which have slowly progressed to involve the feet and hands symmetrically, in a stocking-glove pattern. There are no other associated neurological deficits. On examination, there is diffuse desquamation of the palms and soles with hyperkeratosis. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a smelting industry worker presenting with neuropathy as well as desquamation and hyperkeratosis of palms and soles is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. The Burtonian line is seen in chronic lead poisoning and is not a feature of arsenic poisoning.

Chronic arsenic poisoning occurs in persons engaged in smelting or refining ore and in the subliming of white arsenic during the manufacture of sheep dips, weed killers, paints, dyes, cosmetics, drugs, etc. Chronic poisoning may follow acute poisoning, especially after recovery from large doses of arsenic.

The clinical features are as follows.

System involved Symptoms
Skin Raindrop pigmentation, melanosis, Bowen disease, facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, alopecia 
Nails Aldrich-Mees Lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails)
Neurologic

Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory and motor polyneuritis (stocking-glove distribution) distal weakness, Encephalopathy, tremors, axonal degeneration
G I tract Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss
Liver Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
Hematologic Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis
Cardiovascular Blackfoot disease due to platelet activation and prolonged QT interval, ventricular hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries

Diagnosis: Urinary level of >100 mg/24 hours suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Chemical Laboratory tests to detect arsenic poisoning are:

  • Marsh test
  • Reinsch test
  • Gutzeit test

Dimercaprol is the chelating agent of choice for arsenic poisoning.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with painful swelling of the right calf muscle, 7 days after her knee replacement surgery. On examination, her heart rate 70 beats per min, her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and her SPO2 is 96% on room air.  The test shown below is positive. She has no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. Based on Well's criteria, which is the most appropriate investigation to be carried out next?
questions.solution:
From the clinical vignette, Well's score is 7.5, indicating that she is at high risk for developing a pulmonary embolism for which she should undergo a helical CT Pulmonary Angiography. The clinical stem with calf pain and swelling following surgery, along with the given image showing Homan's sign (calf tenderness on forced ankle dorsiflexion) points to the diagnosis of Deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Wells score criteria help in the estimation of the clinical likelihood of DVT and PE. Calculation of Well's score in this case:

  • Signs and symptoms of DVT = 3
  • No alternative diagnosis = 3
  • Heart rate is 70 beats per min. (<100) = 0
  • Surgery in previous 4 weeks = 1.5
  • No previous PE = 0
  • No Hemoptysis = 0
  • No cancer (no significant weight loss) = 0

Total score = 7.5

Well's criteria (Three-tiered clinical probability assessment)

  • High risk >6
  • Moderate risk 2-6
  • Low risk <2

Patients with a low-to-moderate likelihood of DVT or PE should undergo diagnostic evaluation with d-dimer testing alone. However, patients with a high clinical risk of venous thromboembolism should skip d-dimer testing and undergo imaging as the next step in the diagnostic algorithm.

Other options:

Option A: D dimer rises in the presence of DVT or PE because of the breakdown of fibrin by plasmin. Elevation of d-dimer indicates endogenous although often clinically ineffective thrombolysis. The sensitivity of the d-dimer is >80% for DVT (including isolated calf DVT) and >95% for PE.

Option C: The most frequently cited abnormality, in addition to sinus tachycardia, is the S1Q3T3 sign: an S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III

Option D: An intraluminal filling defect is diagnostic. However, venous ultrasonography has replaced contrast phlebography as the main diagnostic test for suspected DVT. It is only used in complex situations where there is a discrepancy between clinical suspicion and noninvasive testing.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is referred for evaluation of a spinal deformity in the mid-thoracic region. She complains of pain during sports and physical activities at school, which is relieved on resting. On examination, the right shoulder is slightly higher than the left and on forward bending, a right-sided mid-thoracic prominence was noted. Identify the true statements about the progression of this condition.
  1. Progression is more likely in girls than boys
  2. Single curves more likely to progress than double curves
  3. Thoracic curves more likely to progress than lumbar curves
  4. Curves in older children more likely to progress than younger
  5. Greater angled curves are less likely to progress than smaller angled curves.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, and statements 1 and 3 are the true statements about the progression of the condition. 

The X-ray shows a spine with scoliosis, the curve being convex to the right with Cobb's angle of 40 degrees.

Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis is diagnosed when the spinal deformity is recognized in a child after the age of 10 years but before skeletal maturity. This is the most common type of idiopathic scoliosis. It characteristically includes a lateral curvature of the spine with rotation of the vertebrae. The primary thoracic curves are usually convex to the right, and lumbar curves are usually convex to the left. Intermediate (thoracolumbar) and combined (double primary) curves may also occur.

Progression of Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis: Progression is defined as an increase of Cobb's angle by 5 degrees or more, measured in two or more visits. Factors affecting progression are:

  • Girls>Boys: Girls are more likely to progress than boys
  • Younger children>Older children: Incidence of progression decreases as the child gets older. Curve progression occurs during the rapid adolescent growth spurt before the onset of menses
  • Risser sign of 0 at presentation: More likely to progress
  • Double curves > single curves: Double curves are more likely to progress than single curves
  • Thoracic curves > lumbar curves: Single thoracic curves tend to be more progressive than single lumbar curves. 
  • Curve magnitude: Incidence of progression increases with the curve magnitude

Idiopathic scoliosis is subclassified as :

questions.text: A full-term male infant was born at 37 weeks by vaginal delivery to a teenage mother. An incidental finding of protruding, violaceous, and wet intestinal loops through the abdomen was noted. There was no membrane surrounding it. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is describing a case of gastroschisis, which can be associated with intestinal atresia.

Gastroschisis is the commonest defect in babies born to teenage mothers. The fetal bowel prolapses through a defect to the right of the umbilicus. The bowel is non­rotated, foreshortened, and is covered by a fibrin­ous peel, but not covered by a membrane.

Gastroschisis has a good prognosis although gut dysmotility may delay recovery. Some infants have associated intestinal atresia, and males may have undescended testes.

The exposed intestines should be gently placed in a sterile clear plastic bag or a silo (a plastic or plastic bag attached to the abdominal wall) after delivery. The infant should be transferred to a tertiary referral center for surgical correction and evaluation for other associated anomalies. 

 

Other options:

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (omphalocele, macrosomia, hypoglycemia), trisomies 13 and 18, and meningomyelocele are associated with omphaloceles. Other conditions associated with omphalocele are conjoined twins and imperforate anus. 

An omphalocele is a herniation or protrusion of the abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord. The liver may also protrude in some cases. The sac is covered with peritoneum without overlying skin. Immediate surgical repair is essential.

questions.text: A 62-year-old known hypertensive woman presented to the emergency with spasticity of both lower limbs. Further neurological examination showed regular, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of a muscle subjected to sudden, maintained stretch. Which of the following is false regarding this phenomenon?

choices.text: Only sustained clonus with five or more beats is considered abnormal
Clonus may also occur in spinal cord injury that disrupts the descending cortical input to a spinal glycinergic inhibitory interneuron called the Renshaw cell
The stretch reflex–inverse stretch reflex sequence may contribute to this response
This is characteristic of states in which decreased γ-motor neuron discharge is present

questions.solution:
The case scenario indicates clonus. A characteristic of states in which increased γ-motor neuron discharge is present is clonus. 

All the other options are correct.

When a muscle is subjected to a sudden and maintained stretch, there occur regular, repetitive, and rhythmic contractions. This is called clonus. Ankle clonus is a typical example.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a schematic representation of the blue-white assay used in the screening of recombinant vectors for inserted DNA fragments. It uses the phenomenon of complementation (αlpha-complementation of the β-galactosidase gene).

Blue white assay: The DNA of interest is ligated into a vector. The vector is then inserted into a competent host cell viable for transformation, which is then grown in the presence of X-gal (X-gal detects active β-galactosidase). Cells transformed with vectors containing recombinant DNA will produce white colonies whereas cells transformed with non-recombinant plasmids (i.e. only the vector) grow into blue colonies.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the casualty with severe bleeding following a road traffic accident. He is a known cardiac disease patient on anticoagulant therapy.  As an intern, you were asked to collect blood for coagulation studies. Which colour vacutainer will you pick?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate.

The benefits of trisodium citrate are that the calcium ion is neutralized more rapidly in citrate.

Other anticoagulants are unacceptable for coagulation studies. The labile factors (factors V and VIII) are unstable in oxalate (grey), whereas heparin (green) and EDTA (lavender) directly inhibit the coagulation process and interfere with end-point determinations. Also, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) tests are more sensitive to the presence of heparin (green).

questions.text: A male patient weighing 50 kg has acute severe asthma, for which theophylline infusion is planned. The target plasma concentration is 10 mg/L. The volume of distribution of theophylline is  0.6 L/kg. What will be the loading dose in this patient for intravenous administration?
questions.solution:
The loading dose of theophylline in this patient for intravenous administration is 300mg. 

The loading dose is the amount or dose of a drug given to achieve target plasma concentration quickly when the treatment requires an immediate therapeutic response. It is usually given at the onset of therapy.

Loading Dose is given by the formula: 

Where, 

  • Vd - Volume of distribution (liters) 
  • Cp - target serum level (mg/L)
  • F - bioavailability factor

In the above patient, target plasma concentration (Cp) = 10 mg/L & volume of distribution (Vd) = 0.6 L/kg 

Hence, total Vd = 0.6 x 50 = 30 L

For intravenous route: F=1

Therefore, on substituting these values in the above equation,

Loading dose = 10 mg/L x 30L = 300 mg 

Note: The loading dose of 300 mg is usually not given as a single intravenous injection; it would be given as an infusion or as divided doses administered over a short period to reduce the toxicity associated with high plasma levels.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presented with complaints of mucoid diarrhea and abdominal pain for 1 week.  The stool microscopy revealed the following.  What is the appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Mucoid diarrhea, abdominal pain and stool microscopy showing the rhabditiform larva of S. stercoralis are suggestive of strongyloidiasis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition would be ivermectin.

Strongyloidiasis is caused by the nematode Strongyloides stercoralis. It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. Patients often present with larva currens due to larval migration or recurrent urticaria. Gastrointestinal symptoms include abdominal pain aggravated by food ingestion, diarrhea, gastrointestinal bleeding and weight loss. Eosinophilia is seen. Diagnosis is by detection of rhabditiform larvae in stool samples. Eggs with rhadbitiform larvae can also be seen, as shown below.

questions.text: A patient complaining of vertigo without hearing loss has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon performs a diagnostic maneuver and cautiously performs a therapeutic maneuver. What is the diagnostic maneuver?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo without hearing loss is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is characterized by vertigo, recurrent brief (<1 minute) episodes triggered by specific head movements, and is not associated with hearing loss or other neurological symptoms.

It is thought to be caused by the dislodgement of crystals of calcium carbonate from the degenerating macula of the utricle. When this crystal settles on the cupula of the posterior canal, it causes displacement of the cupula and vertigo. 

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, cerebellum, temporal lobe, or multiple sclerosis) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps to differentiate a peripheral from a central lesion.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver: The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested. Then the examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus. 

The features of nystagmus differentiate between BPPV and central lesions: 

Nystagmus BPPV Central lesions
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration <1 minute >1 minute
Direction fixed, towards the lower-placed ear changing
The result on repetitions of the test nystagmus is not seen (fatiguable) nystagmus persists (nonfatiguable)
Symptoms during the test severe vertigo Absent/mild

The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which displaces the otolith out of the posterior canal. This ends the sensation of vertigo with positional changes relieving the symptoms.

questions.text: The following lesion is seen in a 25-year-old man who came to a primary health centre 5 days after he had unprotected sexual intercourse. On palpation the ulcers were painful. Suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy was present on the right side. The patient has no previous history of drug allergy. Which kit will be used for the management of this particular sexually transmitted disease?
questions.solution:
The appearance of painful genital ulcers, along with unilateral suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy, 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse best fits the symptom cluster of a non - herpetic genital ulcer. The treatment of which is kit 3 / white kit in case of no penicillin allergy.  

The above-shown clinical image and the findings are consistent with a diagnosis of chancroid.

Soft Chancre/Chancroid:

  • The causative organism is  Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • The incubation period is 3 to 10 days.
  • It presents with multiple painful ulcers on genitals.
  • It may be accompanied by unilateral painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units + tab. Azithromycin 1 gm single dose

Note: In the syndromic approach to sexually transmitted infections, kit assignment based on the identification of a cluster of symptoms rather than making an actual diagnosis is given emphasis.

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.
